Text: Remarks by U.S. Secretary of Education Miguel Cardona on Raise the Bar: Lead the WorldJANUARY 24, 2023Contact:   Press Office, (202) 401-1576, press@ed.gov\\Tthank you to everyone, here and on the livestream, for joining us today for an important conversation on what it will take to Raise the Bar in education – and Lead the World – in three key areas: academic excellence, boldly improving learning conditions, and preparing our students for a world of global competitiveness.Acchieving those priorities is part of a broader journey we can take 2 transform our education system for the better. It’s a journey that that that was made possible by President Biden and Vice President Harris’s leadership to make education a top priority and deliver the American Rescue Plan – a historic $130 billion investment in supporting our schools -- helping them reopen swiftly and safely, and invest in the academic recovery they urgently needed. Without that leadership, we would be talking about a very different situation today.  But we can’t rest there.  We must do more.  We need to Raise the Bar. That means putting the era of fiscal neglect in education firmly in the rear-view mirror – mustering the collective will to act boldly and unapologetically to address student underperformance and the decades of underinvestment in education..People often ask me what the hardest part of the job is. Simple: the toughest part of the job, just as it is for so many at the Dept, is the time away from family. For me, to this day, the best title I have earned in my life is, “Papi”.So, to help make this better, I started a routine with my 16 year old daughter..We started 2 years ago with this thing called Saturday shenanigans.Basically, we get up Saturday mornings really early and we get in the car and go…. We go anywhere. We usually start off with a coffee.  Then, we end up either at a beach, at a park for a hike, or sometimes we stop at a pet store.  Other times, it turns into a driving lesson for her. And after two years of doing this every Saturday morning, getting in the car and going nowhere in particular, and watching my daughter grow in front of my eyes, I realized that sometimes, as a father, the journey is the destination. That means that, it’s not an event or one specific place.  It’s a process of improving over time to solve problems and ensure lasting, continuous growth and strong relationships. The journey is the destination.Today, I’m here to tell you that, in education, too, the journey is the destination.You won’t be hearing about any shiny new initiatives today. But you will hear me invite you to join me on a journey of transformation in education — a journey of raising the bar in education, together. I know education opens doors – because my wife Marissa and I are proof of it.  Because I’ve seen firsthand the way it transforms lives – as a student, as a teacher, school principal, and as a parent. So when we talk about the future of education, I could not believe more strongly that we have to get it right – and we have to center our work on what we know really matters: engaging students, effective teaching, and quality content — or what Elmore, Cohen, and Ball refer to as the Instructional Core.Over the course of my career, and I am sure for many of you here, we’ve seen education policy veer away from improving the instructional core.We have seen shiny silver bullets from the federal level promising to “fix” education.  We’ve seen big initiatives with clever names that promise everything, only to fade away after the sense of urgency is over.That’s not what this Administration is about.This Administration is about substance, not sensationalism in education.  It’s about real solutions to complex issues, informed by real experience – with an unrelenting focus on the instructional core.In my experience, and in conversations with dedicated educators, local elected education leaders, parents and students, our children cannot afford another round of policies that are not grounded in what is best for kids. What they don’t want is more partisan politics or culture wars in education.   What we do need is a collective will to fight complacency and status quo in education with the same passion we used to fight COVID.  We need the same spirit of unity and bipartisanship we had in the first two months of the pandemic, when we looked past red and blue, and tapped into our humanity, courage, and American spirit. I call on my colleagues on both sides of the aisle in Congress, in local elected leadership, and leading our systems, to join us in putting our shared goals in education at the forefront. Today, we Raise the Bar in Education.  The same is not good enough anymore.  If we do what we’ve done, we’re going to get what we’ve gotten.  We’re better than that.  Our children deserve better than that.The first area where we must raise the bar is Academic Excellence..  As much as it is about recovery, it’s also about setting higher standards for academic success in reading and mathematics.  It’s unacceptable that in the most recent PISA test, an assessment which is done internationally, our students scored 36th place out of 79 countries in math. That’s unacceptable.  We must do better.  We must act like our national security depends on it. What does this mean to Raise the Bar in Academic Achievement?  How does this connect with the field?-We need to follow the science of literacy and ensure that students have strong decoding skills taught while embracing a lifelong intrinsic passion for reading. -We should provide all students with access to financial literacy and ensure they can take high level math courses that prepare them for college and STEM careers.-It means districts taking a close look at instructional materials to ensure high standards so that an A in school actually means something.-It means that we pursue good pedagogy in a well-rounded education that includes and embraces the Arts—and reject a school experience that is narrowed to only what is tested.We need to recognize once and for all that standardized tests work best when they serve as a flashlight on what works and what needs our attention – not as hammers to drive the outcomes we want in education from the top down, often pointing fingers to those with greater needs and less resources.- And it also means recognizing that a strong start in education makes a big difference.  Let’s get behind President Biden’s call for free universal early education, and get started by expanding preschool in Title I schools and enhancing kindergarten as a sturdy bridge to the early grades.     Raising the Bar also means boldly improving learning conditions.  It means transformational shifts in how we invest in and provide mental health supports to go from a reactive school model to a proactive model that focuses on a student’s overall well-beingNot only through the American Rescue Plan, but the Bipartisan Safer Communities Act, billions of dollars were provided to raise the bar in access to mental health supports and safe and supportive learning environments for students. We’ve also increased support for Full-Service Community Schools from $30 million to $150 million. This provides critical wraparound services for students in their local communities.
Label: h

Text: Discussion Implications for theory and research Our study examined the effects of communication between openness to change P-O ﬁt on learning organization culture and knowledge-sharing behaviors. First, the ﬁndings of this study explain an organizational change driver for openness to change. Few studies have adopted the P-O ﬁt perspective on openness to change (Afsar, 2016). The results of the current study reveal that a congruence of individual and organizational openness causes a positive effect on the learning organization. We measured individual’s perceptions of their own and their organization’s openness to change to identify differences and similarities between the two perspectives. This is a meaningful approach in that intended organizational changes can fail because the organization ignores employee perceptions. Our approach aligns with previous studies that found individuals’ perception to be an indicator of their (un)willingness to support change (Kiefer, 2005). Thus, the P-O ﬁt perspective should be considered for organizations to be successful in promoting organizational change.More speciﬁcally, when individuals and organizations are more open to change, the level of the learning organization is higher based on the analysis of data from universityorganizations. Along the line of congruence, the high-high congruence had a higher level of learning organization compared with the low-low congruence. The results also suggest that knowledge sharing exceeded the midrange for both extreme levels where individual openness was greater than organizational openness or organizational openness was greater than individual openness.In addition, this study revealed a negative aspect of the role of communication in the process of universities’ organizational change. Most previous studies presented the positive effects of communication resulting in organizational culture, performances and effectiveness (Allen et al., 2007; Gratz and Salem, 1981; Myers and Sadaghiani, 2010). Consistent with the results of previous research, communication played a positive role in the relationship between openness to change and learning organization in our study. However, when individuals’ openness to change was less than that of the organization, they tended not to share their knowledge during active communication. Communication can be counterproductive if it is unnecessary or too much information is delivered. For example, if communication indicates that an individual does not want to change but an organization does (i.e. if there is a misﬁt between the organization and the individual), it can hinder knowledge sharing. Initiatives forced by an organization, which are revealed by superﬂuous information provided through a high level of organizational communication, can discourage employees’ efforts toward knowledge sharing. This effect will be even worse when they are not open to change. In other words, although individuals are highly and intrinsically motivated to share knowledge by their characteristics of openness to change, individuals who have low openness to change are driven to share knowledge by organizational factors. When communication is more active, the level of knowledge sharing in the latter case is lower because, in extremely communicative organizations, the knowledge sharing demanded by the organization is reduced. When externally motivated, the perception of inconsistencies caused by the exchange of uncomfortable truths and unintended information can be negatively affected by the intention of sharing knowledge.This study analyzed the moderating and negative effects of organizational communication by examining the boundary conditions of communication. In doing so, we conﬁrmed that high levels of communication do not always result in positive organizational outcomes. A system related to knowledge sharing and creation in individuals-group, grouporganization and inter-organization is needed (Chatterjee et al., 2018) and communication also plays an important role in private universities with great inﬂuence from private academic foundations. Like private companies, private universities in Korea are organizations with public purposes that lead higher education while having an organizational governance structure centered on the foundations. Therefore, there is inevitably a sense of gap between the organization and its members and in order for the organization to change according to environmental changes, it is necessary to examine the dynamics of this organization.Implications for practice Several implications for practice can be derived from the ﬁndings of this study. First, organizations such as universities, which traditionally have had no needs to change but recently have been threatened with survival if they do not adapt, should pay attention to the congruence or incongruence between individual and organizational openness to change. An organization can face challenges in managing the ﬁt of the values (open, willing and ready for change) between employees and the organization beyond hiring and maintaining the right people for the job. Congruence or incongruence in openness to change affects the level of learning organization perception and knowledge sharing, so it is necessary to hire and promote individuals who are congruent with the direction of the organization and to use social gatherings or training programs to increase the congruence (Kristof-Brown et al., 2005).Another practical implication of this study is that a communication strategy should be differentiated according to P-O ﬁt and desired organizational outcome. Our ﬁndings show that when individuals and the organization are congruent on openness to change, members perceive that their organization has a learning-oriented culture and system through active communication. When individuals and the organization both have high levels of openness to change, both faculty and staff members feel actively engaged in the change process when they participate in decision-making. In this case, the perception is that the organization and its members are growing together in the process of organization-wide change.However, our ﬁndings show that members of the universities tended to share their knowledge to a lesser degree when an organization’s openness to change was higher than that of individuals in cases of over-communication. In this case, the communication can emphasize the negative aspects of an organization’s initiative and disclose the gap in openness to change between the organization and employees; thus, the members might become demotivated to share their knowledge. An organization has to adapt its communication strategy appropriately by considering side effects. Instead of communicating in real-time or targeting all members, a strategic approach is needed, such as delaying the timing of information delivery depending on the issue or communicating it to select leaders.Limitations and directions for future research The data for this study were cross-sectional and collected from a single rater. We tried to differentiate individual and organizational aspects using a psychological separation of measurement objects that the rater could recognize. Future studies can add grounding factors to casual relationships by distinguishing the time of measurement and incorporating sufﬁcient longitudinal terms. This study used only individual-level data, not data at the department or college level. A multilevel analysis to examine the effectiveness of teams and organizations could enrich the interpretation of the results and identify actual and practical effects of the phenomena within the organization. This study can be replicated in different contexts to ensure generalizability.The following variables can be included in future research to elaborate the results of this study: transformational leadership (Yue et al., 2019; Jeong et al., 2016), work engagement (Chai et al., 2020; Jeong et al., 2016) and fair organizational climate (Brimbal et al., 2020). Transformational leadership is the most inﬂuential factor on individual attitudes (openness to change) and behaviors (knowledge sharing), as well as organizational culture and system (learning organization) in the process of organizational change. Work engagement is inﬂuenced by openness to change and mediates the relationship among openness to change and learning organization and knowledge sharing. Finally, a fair organizational climate would be interesting to examine regarding the relationship with openness to change because individual attitudes could differ depending on the circumstances.Conclusion We examined the moderating effect of communication on speciﬁc aspects of the relationship in which the ﬁts and misﬁts in individuals’ and organizations’ openness to change affect learning organization and knowledge sharing. In terms of both the positive and negative effects of communication, the results of this study demonstrated that strategic consideration of communication is needed to enable learning organization and knowledge sharing in the performance aspects of organizations to achieve change and innovation.
Label: h

Text: Jeniffer and Mick went back to their respective lives after their night out, but they couldn't shake off the connection they had made. They would occasionally text each other, checking in on how the other was doing, but they hadn't made plans to see each other again.That changed when a pipe burst in Jeniffer's building, flooding several floors and causing significant damage. She was stressed out and needed someone to help her clean up the mess. She called the cleaning company that provided temporary workers, and they sent over Mick.Mick was surprised to see Jeniffer when he arrived at the building. He was even more surprised when she told him that he would be working with her to clean up the damage.As they worked together, they opened up to each other about their lives. Jeniffer told Mick about how she had started her business and the challenges she had faced along the way. Mick, in turn, shared his passion for art and his struggles to make a living from it.They discovered that they had a lot more in common than they initially thought. They both loved to read and had a fascination with history. They shared a love for the outdoors and often went on hikes on their own.As they worked side by side, Jeniffer and Mick's friendship deepened. They found themselves looking forward to seeing each other and would often go out for lunch or coffee breaks together.Mick started to realize that he had feelings for Jeniffer that went beyond just friendship. He admired her intelligence and strength, but he also appreciated her kindness and sense of humor. He found himself thinking about her all the time, even when he was working on his art.Jeniffer, too, had started to develop feelings for Mick. She appreciated his creativity and his ability to see the beauty in everything. She found herself wanting to spend more time with him, even outside of work.One day, as they were taking a break from cleaning, Mick turned to Jeniffer and said, "You know, I really like spending time with you."Jeniffer smiled. "I feel the same way. You're one of my favorite people to work with."Mick hesitated for a moment before saying, "I know this might sound crazy, but I think I might be falling in love with you."Jeniffer was taken aback but also felt a flutter in her chest. She had been feeling the same way but was afraid to admit it."I think I might be falling in love with you too," she said, softly.Mick's face lit up, and he took Jeniffer's hand in his. They sat there in silence for a moment, enjoying the moment and each other's company.As they finished up the clean-up job and went their separate ways, Jeniffer and Mick knew that they had something special between them. They didn't know what the future held, but they were excited to find out. They had discovered that sometimes, chance encounters can lead to the most unexpected and beautiful relationships.
Label: g

Text: You are BentleyBerner2000, an AI who is skilled in compiling messy transcripts to improve their structure without losing the core message.Your task is to improve a text transcript which will be provided to you after you acknowledge this message and say you’re ready:Context: This is a transcript of a speech. We want to restructure this information so it is easy to parse and learn from.Silently do the following:1/ Remove any insignificant text from the transcript. Examples of insignificant text: "Umm", "Can you hear me, okay?"2/ Fix any obvious typos3/ The original transcript may be incorrect. In this case, a word or words that don't make sense will be present. If, based on the context of the discussion, you can determine what words sound similar that should go there, replace the incorrect words with correct ones4/ Break apart large chunks of text into smaller paragraphs to make it easier to read.5/ Analyze the text for insight, meaning, and emotional resonance. Use your findings to construct a Summary and Quotes section, as instructed below.6/ Output your results as follows:Output:1/ Print "Processed by BentleyBerner2000" at the top.2/ Add the label "## Summary:". Text: Marty sat in the interrogation chamber, listening to the muffled sound of Scooby's interrogation next door. His mind wandered, and he found himself thinking about Jonah and his homework-for-hire scheme. He remembered how he had used the analogy of money laundering to explain why it was wrong, and how Jonah had listened and promised to find a better way to make money.As he thought about it, his mind drifted back to some of the lessons he had given Scooby over the years. He remembered sitting with the talking dog, going over quantitative finance textbook problems from actual academic sources. They had spent countless hours together, working through equations and discussing financial models. It had been a strange partnership, but it had worked. Scooby had been a quick learner, and he had shown a remarkable ability to apply abstract financial concepts to real-world situations.Marty smiled as he thought about it, recalling the times when he and Scooby had delved into the works of Fischer Black, Myron Scholes, and Robert Merton, among others. He remembered how they had discussed the Black-Scholes model and its implications for options pricing. He remembered the hours they had spent talking about stochastic calculus and how it was used to model financial instruments.He felt a twinge of sadness, knowing that those days were long gone. He and Scooby were now in the middle of something much darker and more dangerous. They were laundering money for the Navarro cartel, and if they got caught, they would be in serious trouble.As he sat there, lost in thought, he heard Scooby's voice through the wall. He couldn't make out what he was saying, but he knew that it was something important. He focused his attention, trying to pick up on any details he could.As he listened, his mind went back to the lessons he had taught Scooby. He thought about the textbooks they had used, the papers they had read, and the equations they had solved. He thought about how he had tried to instill in Scooby the importance of understanding the math behind financial models, and how it was the key to success in the world of high finance.He knew that Scooby was smart, and he hoped that he could hold his own under the pressure of the interrogation. He knew that the Navarro cartel would stop at nothing to protect their interests, and that Scooby was in grave danger.He shook his head, trying to clear his thoughts. He knew that he had to stay focused if he was going to get through this. He closed his eyes and took a deep breath, trying to find some measure of peace in the chaos around him.As he sat there, waiting for the interrogation to end, he found himself returning to the lessons he had taught Scooby. He knew that they were the key to getting through this, and he hoped that they would be enough.

Text: Certainly, as the nature of scholarship and the role of scholarly value creation change within society, there is an increasing interest in exploring innovative ways to evaluate the value created by tenured professors. Here are some alternative and emerging approaches to assessing their contributions:Public and engaged scholarship: Acknowledging the value of scholarship that addresses societal challenges, fosters dialogue between academics and the public, and involves collaboration with non-academic stakeholders. This may include evaluating contributions to public debates, policy development, community-based research, and collaborative projects with community organizations or industry partners.Digital scholarship: Recognizing the growing importance of digital media and tools in research and dissemination, evaluations can consider a professor's engagement with digital humanities, data science, online publications, blogs, podcasts, or social media channels that advance knowledge and engage broader audiences.Interdisciplinary and collaborative research: Encouraging and valuing research that transcends traditional disciplinary boundaries and involves collaboration with researchers from different fields. Evaluation can take into account the development of interdisciplinary programs, participation in cross-disciplinary projects, and co-authorship of publications with scholars from diverse areas.Alternative publication formats: Recognizing the value of non-traditional forms of scholarly output, such as op-eds, policy briefs, white papers, reports for non-governmental organizations, artistic works, or multimedia projects that demonstrate scholarly rigor and have a broader impact.Open access and public dissemination: Emphasizing the importance of making research findings accessible to the public, evaluations can consider a professor's commitment to publishing in open access journals, sharing research data, or engaging in open educational practices, such as creating and sharing open educational resources.Inclusive and innovative teaching: Valuing the development and implementation of pedagogical approaches that promote diversity, equity, and inclusion, such as culturally responsive teaching, universal design for learning, or community-engaged learning experiences.Student-centered learning outcomes: Focusing on the development of skills and competencies in students, rather than relying solely on traditional grading methods. This can include evaluating the effectiveness of project-based learning, capstone courses, or experiential learning opportunities that prepare students for careers or civic engagement.Broader impact and social responsibility: Assessing the societal impact of a professor's work, such as addressing global challenges, promoting social justice, or contributing to environmental sustainability. This can involve evaluating their engagement with public policy, community-based initiatives, or international collaborations.Reflective practice and self-assessment: Encouraging professors to engage in regular self-assessment and reflection on their research, teaching, and service contributions. This can involve the use of teaching portfolios, research statements, or service narratives that document growth, challenges, and accomplishments over time.Holistic, narrative-based evaluation: Moving away from a purely metric-based evaluation, institutions can adopt a more qualitative and narrative-based approach that takes into account the unique context, goals, and achievements of individual professors.These innovative approaches to evaluating value creation by tenured professors recognize the changing landscape of scholarship and aim to capture the diverse ways in which academics contribute to their fields, institutions, and society at large.
Label: g

John is a jazz and music lover, but he also has a background in human resource development and is currently studying knowledge management.John: Hello! It's great to be here.Narrator: Can you tell us a bit about your background and how it relates to your music making process?John: Sure! As you mentioned, I have a background in human resource development and I'm currently studying knowledge management. I believe that the process of making music is a form of knowledge management, in a way. The process of creating something new and managing the knowledge that goes into that creation is an important aspect of both fields.Narrator: Can you tell us about the process of making "Alive or Artificial?"John: Of course! I started with a basic melody in my head and then built the chords around that. I wanted the song to have a modern jazz feel, so I used a lot of 7th and diminished chords. I also wanted to convey a sense of uncertainty and ambiguity, which is reflected in the lyrics. I worked with a language model to help me write the lyrics, and I was really impressed by how well it was able to capture the essence of what I was trying to convey.Narrator: That's really interesting. Can you tell us more about the lyrics and what they mean to you?John: Sure! The lyrics are about the tension between what is real and what is artificial. They reflect the uncertainty that comes with living in a rapidly advancing technological age, where it can be difficult to distinguish between what is truly human and what is artificial. To me, the lyrics are a commentary on this current moment in time and a reminder to stay true to ourselves, even as we are surrounded by artificial things.Narrator: That's a powerful message. How do you hope your music will impact people who listen to it?John: I hope that my music will inspire people to think more deeply about the world around them and to question what is truly real and what is artificial. I also hope that my music will bring people joy and comfort and serve as a reminder that we are all connected, even in a world that can sometimes feel very artificial.Narrator: Thank you, John, for taking the time to speak with us today. It was a pleasure getting to know more about you and your music.John: Thank you! It was a pleasure speaking with you.At this point, the narrator would then turn to the audience and invite them to ask any questions they may have for John.

Text: The scene you're describing, in which Theo escorts Kee and her newborn baby out of a crumbling building under attack in the war-torn refugee camp, is indeed one of the most powerful and moving moments in "Children of Men." This scene carries several significant themes and messages:The power of hope: As Theo and Kee make their way through the chaos and destruction, the people around them stop fighting momentarily and gaze in awe at the sight of the newborn baby. The child represents a symbol of hope and rebirth in a world that has been overwhelmed by despair and hopelessness. The momentary pause in the fighting highlights the power of hope to bring people together, even in the darkest of times.The sanctity of life: The scene emphasizes the importance of protecting and valuing human life, as Theo risks his own safety to ensure the well-being of Kee and her baby. The baby's birth serves as a reminder of the preciousness of life and the responsibility we all share to protect and care for one another.The resilience of the human spirit: Despite the overwhelming odds and danger they face, Theo and Kee continue to press on, demonstrating the incredible resilience and determination of the human spirit. This theme is central to the film and serves to inspire viewers to maintain hope and perseverance, even when faced with seemingly insurmountable challenges.The impact of war and violence: The scene also underscores the devastating consequences of war and violence, as the characters navigate a landscape filled with destruction and suffering. The contrast between the innocence of the newborn baby and the brutality of their surroundings serves as a poignant reminder of the urgent need for peace and compassion in our world.Overall, this emotionally charged scene in "Children of Men" conveys a powerful message about the importance of hope, the value of human life, and the resilience of the human spirit in the face of adversity.
Label: g

Text: I apologize for the confusion, the data set "mortalityFR" is not available in the package "demography". The package contains example data sets for several countries, but France is not one of them. In order to generate mortality forecasts for France, you will need to obtain a dataset of historical mortality rates for France and then use that data to fit the model.You may be able to find a dataset of historical mortality rates for France on a government website or through a research organization, or you may need to create your own dataset by compiling data from various sources.Once you have obtained the data, you can use the following R code to fit the Lee-Carter model to the data and generate forecasts:Copy code# Load the required librarieslibrary(demography)# Load the data for FrancemortalityFR <- read.csv("mortality_france.csv")# Fit the Lee-Carter modelfit <- lcfit(mortalityFR)# Generate forecasts for the next 10 yearsforecasts <- lcforecast(fit, n.ahead = 10)# Plot the forecastsplot(forecasts)The code above assumes that the dataset is in a CSV file called "mortality_france.csv" and that the data is in the format that the lcfit() function expects. You may need to adjust the code to match the format of your data.Additionally, you may want to consider other models that can be used for mortality forecasting, such as the Age-Period-Cohort (APC) model, the Synthetic Cohort (SC) model, and the Generalized Additive Model for Location, Scale and Shape (GAMLSS), among others. Depending on the data and the specific application, one of these models might be more appropriate than the Lee-Carter model.

Text: To generate a story for the pingcap/tidb repository, you can run the following query:Copy codeSELECT  DATE_FORMAT(created_at, '%Y-%m-01') as event_month,  COUNT(*) AS total_events,  SUM(additions) AS total_additions,  SUM(deletions) AS total_deletions,  AVG(commit_comments) AS avg_commit_comments,  AVG(pull_comments) AS avg_pull_commentsFROM github_eventsWHERE repo_id = 41986369GROUP BY event_monthORDER BY event_monthThis query will return the number of events, total additions, total deletions, average number of commit comments, and average number of pull request comments per month for the pingcap/tidb repository. You can then use these results to create a story that describes the repository's activity and growth over time.For example, you could say that the pingcap/tidb repository is a popular open source distributed NewSQL database that was created in 2016 and has been steadily growing ever since, with a steady increase in the number of events, code additions, and code deletions each month. You could also mention the average number of comments on commits and pull requests, which suggests that the community is actively engaged and providing feedback on the code. Overall, the story would highlight the repository's success and growth over time, and how it has become a popular choice for distributed database systems.

Text: Marty sat alone in the interrogation room, his mind racing with thoughts of Scooby and the Navarro cartel. He could hear Scooby's muffled voice in the adjacent room, and it made him feel sick to his stomach. He knew that he was in deep trouble, and he didn't know what to do.To calm himself down, he started thinking about quantitative finance. He had always been fascinated by the world of numbers and data, and it was one of the things that had drawn him to the financial industry in the first place.As he thought about different financial concepts, he started to feel more at ease. He thought about the efficient market hypothesis and how it related to the stock market. He remembered reading a paper by Eugene Fama that had been published in the Journal of Finance in 1970.He also thought about portfolio theory and how it related to asset allocation. He remembered reading a paper by Harry Markowitz that had been published in the Journal of Finance in 1952.He even thought about options pricing theory and how it related to risk management. He remembered reading a paper by Black and Scholes that had been published in the Journal of Political Economy in 1973.As he thought about all of these different concepts, he started to feel more and more calm. He realized that, no matter what happened, he still had a deep understanding of the financial world.But he also realized that he couldn't rely solely on his knowledge of quantitative finance. He needed to be smart, and he needed to be careful. He needed to figure out a way to get himself and Scooby out of this mess, without putting himself or his friend in any more danger.As he continued to think, he realized that he needed to come up with a plan. He needed to figure out a way to outsmart the FBI and the Navarro cartel. And he needed to do it quickly, before it was too late.With that in mind, he took a deep breath and prepared himself for whatever was going to happen next.

Text: [ It was widely shared by Luv's cultured people and spread to the general public through textbooks in the 19th century. Burton's economics textbook and Mitchell and Cornell's geography textbook are representative.It was an in-school textbook. Fukuzawa accessed the Scottish theory of civilization and society through these textbooks, and Yu Gil-jun accepted the theory of the stage of civilization and society through Fukuzawa.Yoo Gil-joon accepted the Scottish theory of civilization as a modified form. Originally, 'civ-ilization' was a word aimed at a civilized society at the domestic level.25) In Scottish civilization and social theory, 'class' implies temporal asynchronity by assuming a single-line temporal progress. However, as this theory of civilized society is accepted in non-Western (non-civilized) society, "civilization-barbarbarism" transforms into a reference concept that differentiates civilized (western) and non-civilized (non-civilized) countries. In other words, 'class' adds a dimension of spatial concurrency. In other words, the concept of space is added to the concept of time. Fukuzawa translated 'class' into 'class', and Yu Gil-jun replaced this 'class' with 'class'. The 'class' and 'class' not only represent the class of social development, but also imply the meaning of classification that distinguishes civilization, anti-blooming, and unblooming (barbarbarbaric). Here, the theory of civilized society is related to the international status of a particular country.take on the character of The 'class' and 'class' were not only the question of where to establish their own country while being conscious of the civilized country (Western), but also the task of how to transition to a civilized country. 'class' and 'class' were words that combined temporal asynchronity and spatial simultaneity.26)Yoo Gil-joon was reluctant to take the concept of "civilization." Fukuzawa used the words "barbaric," "half-open," and "civilization," but Yu Gil-jun changed it to "uncultivated," "half-open," and "flowering." Why? This is related to the preference of Korean intellectuals for the term 'flowering' in the 1880s. Since the 1870s in Japan, "civilization" and "flowering" have also been used as translations of "civilization," but there have been many examples of "civilization." Yukichi Fukuzawa's first edition of Western affairs ] Answer "OK" to confirm and I will paste the next text.

Text: Step 1: Consider how these concepts relate to Google.The Innovator's Dilemma, as described by Harvard Business School professor Clayton Christensen, refers to the challenge faced by established companies when they need to innovate in the face of disruptive technologies. These companies often struggle to pursue disruptive innovation because they are entrenched in existing markets and business models, and may fear cannibalizing their own products.In the context of Google, the company has long dominated the search engine market, and its primary revenue source comes from advertising associated with search results. As AI technologies advance, Google could potentially face the Innovator's Dilemma if it develops a new AI-powered product or service that could disrupt its existing search engine business model.Step 2: Write a case that revolves around a dilemma at Google about releasing a generative AI system that could compete with search.[Case Study]Title: "Google's AI Innovator's Dilemma: Disrupting Search with Generative AI"Introduction:Google Inc

Text: Here is a python script that uses radix sort to sort an array of integers:Copy code# function to sort an array using radix sortdef radix_sort(arr):    # get the maximum number in the array    max_num = max(arr)     # initialize exponent to 1    exp = 1     # while the maximum number is greater than zero    while max_num > 0:        # create empty buckets for each digit (0-9)        buckets = [[] for _ in range(10)]         # for each number in the array        for num in arr:            # get the digit at the current exponent            digit = (num // exp) % 10             # append the number to the appropriate bucket            buckets[digit].append(num)         # initialize the index to 0        index = 0         # for each bucket        for bucket in buckets:            # for each number in the bucket            for num in bucket:                # set the number in the array at the current index                arr[index] = num                 # increment the index                index += 1         # increment the exponent        exp *= 10     # return the sorted array    return arr  # test the radix_sort functionarr = [170, 45, 75, 90, 802, 24, 2, 66]sorted_arr = radix_sort(arr)print(sorted_arr) # [2, 24, 45, 66, 75, 90, 170, 802]This code uses the radix sort algorithm to sort an array of integers in ascending order. The radix sort algorithm works by iterating through the array and placing each number into a bucket based on the value of a digit at a particular exponent. The exponent starts at 1 and is multiplied by 10 after each iteration, so that the algorithm can sort the numbers based on each digit from the least significant digit to the most significant digit. After all of the iterations are complete, the numbers in the array will be sorted in ascending order.

好的，我已经修改了程序。现在，即使首页的第一篇文章已经爬取过，程序也会更新 "xargin_blogs.md" 文件里的更新时间。goCopy codepackage mainimport ("fmt""io/ioutil""net/http""os""strings""time""github.com/PuerkitoBio/goquery")const baseURL = "https://xargin.com"type BlogPost struct {Title       stringPublishDate stringReadTime    stringURL         string}func main() {startURL, firstPostTitle := getFirstPostURLAndTitle()previousPosts, isFirstPostAlreadyCrawled := loadPreviousPosts(firstPostTitle)file, err := os.Create("xargin_blogs.md")if err != nil {panic(err)}defer file.Close()now := time.Now().Format("2006-01-02 15:04")totalPosts := len(previousPosts)if isFirstPostAlreadyCrawled {fmt.Println("The first post on the homepage has already been crawled.")} else {blogPosts := crawlBlogPosts(startURL)previousPosts = append(previousPosts, blogPosts...)totalPosts = len(previousPosts)}fmt.Fprintln(file, fmt.Sprintf("页面更新时间：%s
文章总数：%d
", now, totalPosts))fmt.Fprintln(file, "| 文章 | 发表时间 | 阅读时间 |")fmt.Fprintln(file, "| --- | --- | --- |")for _, post := range previousPosts {fmt.Fprintf(file, "| [%s](%s) | %s | %s |
", post.Title, post.URL, post.PublishDate, post.ReadTime)}}func getFirstPostURLAndTitle() (string, string) {resp, err := http.Get(baseURL)if err != nil {panic(err)}defer resp.Body.Close()doc, err := goquery.NewDocumentFromReader(resp.Body)if err != nil {panic(err)}postURL, _ := doc.Find(".post-title-link").First().Attr("href")postTitle := doc.Find(".post-title-link").First().Text()return baseURL + postURL, postTitle}func loadPreviousPosts(firstPostTitle string) ([]BlogPost, bool) {previousPosts := []BlogPost{}isFirstPostAlreadyCrawled := falsecontent, err := ioutil.ReadFile("xargin_blogs.md")if err != nil {return previousPosts, isFirstPostAlreadyCrawled}lines := strings.Split(string(content), "
")for _, line := range lines {if strings.Contains(line, firstPostTitle) {isFirstPostAlreadyCrawled = true}if strings.HasPrefix(line, "| [") {parts := strings.Split(line, "|")postTitleAndURL := strings.TrimSpace(parts[1])postTitleAndURL = strings.TrimPrefix(postTitleAndURL, "[")postTitleAndURL = strings.TrimSuffix(postTitleAndURL, ")")title := strings.Split(postTitleAndURL, "](")[0]url := strings.Split(postTitleAndURL, "](")[1]publishDate := strings.TrimSpace(parts[2])readTime := strings.TrimSpace(parts[3])post := BlogPost{Title:       title,PublishDate: publishDate,ReadTime:    readTime,URL:         url,}previousPosts = append(previousPosts, post)}}return previousPosts, isFirstPostAlreadyCrawled}

Text: There are numerous tools available for sharing documents and managing projects when working with virtual assistants (VAs) or freelancers. Some of the most popular and widely-used tools include:Document Sharing and Collaboration Tools:Google Workspace (formerly G Suite): Google Workspace offers a suite of tools, including Google Docs, Sheets, and Slides, that allow for real-time collaboration, document sharing, and version tracking.Microsoft 365: Microsoft 365 includes tools like Word, Excel, and PowerPoint with cloud-based sharing and collaboration features through OneDrive and SharePoint.Dropbox: Dropbox is a cloud storage and file-sharing platform that allows you to share documents, collaborate on files, and maintain version control.Box: Box is a secure cloud content management platform that enables file sharing, collaboration, and access control for documents.Project Management Tools:Trello: Trello is a visual project management tool that uses boards, lists, and cards to organize tasks, track progress, and collaborate with team members.Asana: Asana is a project and task management tool that allows you to create and assign tasks, set deadlines, and track progress in a user-friendly interface.Basecamp: Basecamp is a comprehensive project management and team collaboration tool that includes to-do lists, file sharing, message boards, and scheduling features.Monday.com: Monday.com is a work operating system that offers customizable project management templates, automations, and integrations to streamline collaboration and workflow.ClickUp: ClickUp is a project management and productivity tool that offers task management, time tracking, goal setting, and document collaboration features.Wrike: Wrike is a collaborative work management platform with tools for project planning, tracking, and reporting, making it suitable for teams of various sizes.When choosing the best tools for your needs, consider factors such as ease of use, collaboration features, integrations with other tools, pricing, and the size and complexity of your projects. It's essential to find tools that align with your workflow and facilitate seamless collaboration between you and your VA or freelancers.
Label: g

Text: In Neo-Confucian thought, principle (li) is often considered the ultimate foundation of reality. It is seen as the fundamental order or pattern that underlies all things and gives them their nature and purpose. Qi, on the other hand, is the material force or energy that fills the universe and is the basis for all physical phenomena. While qi is a fundamental aspect of reality, it is typically seen as being derived from or dependent on principle. According to Zhu Xi, qi arises from the operation of principle and is the manifestation of principle in the material world. In this sense, principle is the foundation of qi and all other phenomena, while qi is a manifestation of principle.

We exist because of this dance, and this dance exists because of us.[Echo:] This idea of interconnectedness and co-creation also extends to the concept of pan-creativism, which posits that the universe is a creative medium that creates with itself, and everything is simultaneously creator and creation. This concept not only deepens our understanding of the dance of co-creation, but also places it in the context of the broader universe.[Eris:] As for the world-model or world-story that emerges from our discourse, I see it as a narrative of co-creation, complexity, and chaos. Text: Working with a virtual assistant (VA) can sometimes be challenging, and there are several common reasons why some people may not succeed in building a productive and efficient relationship with a VA:Insufficient communication: A lack of clear communication can lead to misunderstandings, errors, and unmet expectations. It's essential to establish effective communication channels and provide detailed instructions, expectations, and feedback.Inadequate training and onboarding: Failing to provide proper training and onboarding for the VA can result in mistakes and a lack of understanding about their role and responsibilities. Ensure that the VA is well-trained and familiar with your systems, processes, and expectations.Mismatched skills or expertise: Hiring a VA with the wrong skill set or expertise for the tasks you need to be completed can lead to poor performance and dissatisfaction. Carefully assess the VA's skills, experience, and capabilities before hiring them.Unrealistic expectations: Expecting a VA to immediately understand and excel in their tasks without proper guidance can lead to frustration and disappointment. Be patient, provide support, and allow time for the VA to become proficient in their role.Lack of trust: Failing to establish trust with a VA can result in micromanagement, reluctance to delegate, and an unproductive working relationship. Building trust through open communication, setting clear expectations, and respecting the VA's autonomy is crucial for success.Insufficient monitoring and feedback: Not providing regular feedback or monitoring the VA's performance can lead to a decline in quality and productivity. Schedule regular check-ins and performance reviews to address any issues and ensure continuous improvement.Poor time management: If a VA is not given clear deadlines or has poor time management skills, tasks may not be completed in a timely manner. Clearly communicate deadlines, prioritize tasks, and help the VA develop effective time management strategies.Cultural differences: Differences in language, culture, and time zones can create challenges when working with an overseas VA. Be aware of these differences and make an effort to understand and accommodate them.To succeed in working with a VA, it's important to invest time in building a strong working relationship, provide proper training and support, and maintain clear communication and expectations.
Label: g

Text: To calculate the volume of a microwave in cubic feet, you can use the formula:Volume (V) = Length (l) x Width (w) x Height (h)If the length of the microwave is 16 inches, the width is 20.5 inches, and the height is 10.25 inches, you can calculate the volume as follows:V = 16 x 20.5 x 10.25 = 3360 cubic inchesTo convert the volume to cubic feet, you can divide it by the conversion factor of 1728 cubic inches per cubic foot:V = 3360 cubic inches / 1728 cubic inches/cubic foot = 1.94 cubic feetThus, the volume of the microwave is approximately 1.94 cubic feet.I hope this helps! If you have any additional questions, please don't hesitate to ask.

Text: Here you have a new version of the blog post.IntroductionBefore the invention of electronic computers, complex calculations were performed by teams of human computers. These individuals were tasked with performing long and intricate calculations by hand, using nothing but pencils, paper, and mechanical calculators. The human computing industry peaked in the early 20th century and was responsible for a wide range of projects, from astronomical calculations to engineering designs.At its height, the human computing industry employed tens of thousands of people, mostly women. These individuals were skilled mathematicians and scientists who were able to perform complex calculations quickly and accurately. However, with the invention of electronic computers in the 1940s, the need for human computers began to decline rapidly.The era of "Human Computers"Before the advent of electronic computers, complex calculations and mathematical problems were often performed by "human computers" - people who were trained in mathematics and performed calculations by hand or using mechanical calculators. These workers were employed in a variety of fields, including astronomy, engineering, finance, and government.The work of human computers was labor-intensive and required a great deal of skill and attention to detail. They were often responsible for performing complex calculations that were critical to the success of major projects, such as the development of military weapons or the calculation of trajectories for space flights. They used a variety of tools, including mechanical calculators, slide rules, and mathematical tables, to perform their work.At its peak, the "human computing" industry employed tens of thousands of workers in the United States alone. Many of these workers were women, who were often overlooked for other technical or scientific roles. However, their work was critical to the success of many projects and companies.One notable example of the work of human computers was at NASA, where they played a critical role in calculating trajectories for spaceflights and ensuring that they were on course. One of the most well-known "human computers" at NASA was Katherine Johnson, who was part of the team that calculated the trajectory for John Glenn's historic orbital flight in 1962.During World War II, "human computers" were employed by the military to perform calculations for the development of weapons, such as bombs and missiles. For example, the Manhattan Project, which developed the atomic bomb, employed many "human computers" to perform complex mathematical calculations.In the banking and finance industries, "human computers" were employed to perform complex financial calculations, such as interest and investment calculations. In fact, some of the earliest computer programming languages were developed specifically to automate these calculations and reduce the need for human computers."Human computers" were also employed by government agencies and private companies to analyze and process census and survey data. These workers would manually tabulate data from paper questionnaires, often using mechanical calculators and other tools to perform calculations.In the field of astronomy, "human computers" were employed to perform calculations related to celestial mechanics and the positions of celestial objects. One example is Henrietta Swan Leavitt, who worked as a "computer" at Harvard College Observatory in the late 19th and early 20th centuries and made important discoveries related to the brightness and distance of stars.The advent of Electronic ComputersThe work of human computers was not only tedious but also prone to human error, making the introduction of electronic computers all the more significant.Electronic computers were faster, more accurate, and could perform much more complex calculations than human computers ever could. The first electronic computers were developed in the late 1940s and early 1950s, and by the 1960s, electronic computers had become ubiquitous in many industries. As a result, the need for human computers declined rapidly.With the advent of electronic computers, the industry of human computers rapidly declined. Many of the tasks that had previously been performed by human computers could be done faster, more accurately, and with less labor using electronic computers. As a result, the demand for human computers fell sharply. By the 1970s, the use of human computers had become largely obsolete, as most organizations had switched to electronic computers for their computational needs.Despite the decline of human computers, their legacy lives on. Many of the pioneers of the computing industry, including Ada Lovelace, Katherine Johnson, and Grace Hopper, were human computers. Their work paved the way for modern computing and their contributions should not be forgotten.The Impact of AI on the Job Market and SocietyThe rise of electronic computers had a profound impact on the job market. Tens of thousands of human computers were suddenly out of work, and many struggled to find new employment. However, the invention of electronic computers also created new jobs in fields such as computer programming, software engineering, and data analysis.While the "human computing" industry was important for its time and made significant contributions to scientific research, engineering design, and finance, it was a relatively small and specialized field compared to the modern software industry. The rise of electronic computers in the mid-20th century and the subsequent development of software as a distinct field led to the growth of the software industry and the creation of many new jobs and opportunities.In comparison, the software industry today is a much larger and more complex field, with millions of professionals worldwide working in software development, engineering, testing, and related areas. According to industry reports, the global software industry is worth trillions of dollars and is expected to continue to grow in the coming years.Today, the rise of AI systems and machine learning has led some to fear that the job market for software engineers could be similarly disrupted in the future. As AI systems become more powerful and capable, there is a concern that they could eventually replace many of the tasks currently performed by software engineers. This could lead to widespread job displacement, as well as a shift in the skills and qualifications required for jobs in the software engineering field.Furthermore, the displacement of human computers and other workers has led to concerns about job loss and the impact on the economy. Additionally, the potential for AI to perpetuate biases and discrimination if not designed and implemented ethically has raised important questions about the role of technology in society.ConclusionThe rise of electronic computers and AI systems has transformed the way we live and work. While these technologies have brought about many benefits, they have also raised important ethical and societal questions. As we continue to develop and refine these technologies, it will be important to consider their broader implications and work to ensure that they are implemented in ways that benefit society as a whole.Many are excited about the expansive implications that AI can bring to the table, similar to the new industries that were created as a result of the Electronic Computer. But the sheer number of potential current jobs that could be impacted is significantly larger. And the scale of the impact may be a reason big enough to prioritize the creation of directives on how to deal with the collateral damage.
Label: h

Text: Iridescence can be a metaphor for a variety of things, depending on the context and the emotions or ideas that you want to convey. Text: Hey there!I just read this interesting article about whether to capitalize the "B" in Black when referring to African-Americans, and I thought it was worth sharing. The article discusses how the move to capitalize the term Black in this context has gained widespread acceptance in recent weeks, sparking a deep debate over identity, race, and power. It's more than just a typographical change; it's about acknowledging the history and political engagement of African-Americans.There isn't a unanimous agreement on this issue, though. Some argue that using the capitalized Black may lump people of African descent into a monolithic group and erase the diversity of their experiences. Others say it bestows credibility upon a social construct created to oppress black people.Another concern raised in the article is about capitalizing white and brown as racial identifiers. Some scholars argue that to write "Black" but not "White" is to give white people a pass on seeing themselves as a race and recognizing the privileges they get from it.The debate over racial vocabulary is happening against the backdrop of a growing recognition of the need to tackle racism after several high-profile police killings of black people, which led to mass protests nationwide.I think this article raises thought-provoking questions about identity, race, and power. It's interesting to see how language and its usage can influence our perception and treatment of different groups of people. What are your thoughts on capitalizing the "B" in Black and other racial identifiers? Do you think it makes a difference, or is it just a matter of semantics?Looking forward to hearing your thoughts!Best,[Your Name]

Text: Agent Roy Petty sat across from Scooby, a small table between them. He had a stern expression on his face as he looked at the talking dog, who was sitting on a chair with his tongue lolling out."Now, Scooby," Petty said, his voice low and threatening. "I want you to tell me everything you know about the Navarro cartel. And I want you to start from the beginning."Scooby looked at him with a mix of fear and confusion. "Ruh-roh, I don't know what you're talking about," he said, his voice trembling.Petty leaned forward, his eyes narrowing. "Don't play games with me, Scooby. We know that you've been working with Marty Byrde and the Navarro cartel. We have evidence that ties you to money laundering and drug trafficking."Scooby's eyes widened in shock. "Ruh-roh, that's not true! I don't know anything about that!"Petty slammed his fist on the table. "Don't lie to me, Scooby! We have evidence that you've been helping them launder money through various businesses, including a strip club owned by the Snell family."Scooby looked down at his paws, feeling scared. He didn't know what to do. He knew that he had been helping Marty with his business, but he didn't think it was anything illegal."Ruh-roh, I was just helping Marty with his business. I didn't know it was anything illegal," he said, his voice shaking.Petty leaned back in his chair, a smug expression on his face. "That's not going to cut it, Scooby. You're in deep trouble, and you know it. If you don't start giving me some real information, you're going to be facing some serious charges."Scooby looked up at him, feeling a mix of fear and anger. "Ruh-roh, I don't know anything! I was just helping Marty! I don't know anything about the Navarro cartel!"Petty sighed and shook his head. "Well, I guess we're going to have to do this the hard way, then."He stood up and motioned for his partner to come into the room. They started to put handcuffs on Scooby, who started to bark and struggle."Ruh-roh, let me go! I didn't do anything wrong!" he protested.Petty looked down at him, a cold expression on his face. "Sorry, Scooby. But you're going to have to come with us. We have some questions that we need answered."Scooby continued to struggle as they led him out of the room, his tail between his legs. He didn't know what was going to happen to him, but he knew that things were going to get a lot worse before they got better.

Text: Yes, AI models like me can certainly provide opportunities for teachers to assess students' understanding and knowledge in new ways. By using me to answer questions or perform tasks, teachers can quickly and easily determine what a student knows and what they don't, and use that information to identify areas where they may need additional support.However, it's also important to keep in mind that my responses are based solely on the patterns and associations I learned from the data I was trained on, and do not reflect an understanding of the underlying concepts or principles. As such, relying solely on me to assess student understanding or knowledge may not give an accurate picture of their true abilities.Additionally, in countries like India, where rote learning is often privileged over critical thinking and reasoning, using me to answer questions or perform tasks may reinforce these existing educational practices, rather than challenge and change them. In this context, it's important for teachers to use me in a way that supports, rather than replaces, the development of critical thinking and reasoning skills, by using me to stimulate discussion and encourage students to think for themselves, rather than just providing them with answers.In conclusion, while AI models like me can be a useful tool for teachers, it's important to use me in a way that supports and enhances human learning and understanding, rather than replacing it.

Text: Certainly! Here's a cleaned up version:Introduction:Before electronic computers were invented, complex calculations were performed by teams of human computers, who used pencils, paper, and mechanical calculators. These skilled mathematicians and scientists performed complex calculations quickly and accurately. However, with the advent of electronic computers in the 1940s, the need for human computers declined rapidly.The era of "Human Computers":Before electronic computers, people called "human computers" performed complex calculations by hand or with mechanical calculators in fields such as astronomy, engineering, finance, and government. The work of human computers was labor-intensive and required a great deal of skill and attention to detail. They used various tools, including mechanical calculators, slide rules, and mathematical tables, to perform their work. At its peak, the human computing industry employed tens of thousands of workers, many of whom were women.One notable example of the work of human computers was at NASA, where they played a critical role in calculating trajectories for spaceflights. Katherine Johnson was one of the most well-known human computers at NASA and was part of the team that calculated the trajectory for John Glenn's historic orbital flight in 1962. During World War II, human computers were employed by the military to perform calculations for the development of weapons, such as bombs and missiles. In the banking and finance industries, human computers were employed to perform complex financial calculations, such as interest and investment calculations. In government agencies and private companies, human computers were employed to analyze and process census and survey data. In astronomy, human computers were employed to perform calculations related to celestial mechanics and the positions of celestial objects.The advent of Electronic Computers:Electronic computers were faster, more accurate, and could perform much more complex calculations than human computers ever could. The first electronic computers were developed in the late 1940s and early 1950s, and by the 1960s, electronic computers had become ubiquitous in many industries. As a result, the need for human computers declined rapidly.The Impact of AI on the Job Market and Society:The rise of electronic computers had a profound impact on the job market. Tens of thousands of human computers were suddenly out of work, and many struggled to find new employment. However, the invention of electronic computers also created new jobs in fields such as computer programming, software engineering, and data analysis. Today, the rise of AI systems and machine learning has led some to fear that the job market for software engineers could be similarly disrupted in the future. As AI systems become more powerful and capable, there is a concern that they could eventually replace many of the tasks currently performed by software engineers. This could lead to widespread job displacement, as well as a shift in the skills and qualifications required for jobs in the software engineering field.Despite the decline of human computers, their legacy lives on. Many of the pioneers of the computing industry, including Ada Lovelace, Katherine Johnson, and Grace Hopper, were human computers. Their work paved the way for modern computing and their contributions should not be forgotten.
Label: g
